"**A Whiter Shade of Pale** " is the debut song by the British rock band
[Procol Harum](/wiki/Procol_Harum "Procol Harum"), released 12 May 1967. The
single reached number one in the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK
Singles Chart") on 8 June [1967](/wiki/1967_in_music "1967 in music") and
stayed there for six weeks.[3] Without much promotion, it reached number 5 on
the _Bilboard_ pop chart in the United States.[4] One of the anthems of the
1967 [Summer of Love](/wiki/Summer_of_Love "Summer of Love"), it is one of
fewer than 30 [singles](/wiki/Singles_\(music\) "Singles \(music\)") to have
[sold over 10 million](/wiki/List_of_best-selling_singles "List of best-
selling singles") copies worldwide.[5]

With its haunting [Bach](/wiki/Bach "Bach")-derived instrumental melody,
soulful vocals, and unusual lyrics – by the song's co-authors [Gary
Brooker](/wiki/Gary_Brooker "Gary Brooker"), [Keith Reid](/wiki/Keith_Reid
"Keith Reid")[6] and [Matthew Fisher](/wiki/Matthew_Fisher "Matthew Fisher") –
"A Whiter Shade of Pale" reached No. 1 in several countries when released in
1967. In the years since, it has become an enduring classic. It was the most
played song in the last 75 years in public places in the UK (as of 2009),[7]
and the United Kingdom performing rights group [Phonographic Performance
Limited](/wiki/Phonographic_Performance_Limited "Phonographic Performance
Limited") in 2004 recognised it as the most-played record by British
broadcasting of the past 70 years.[8] Also in 2004, _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ placed "A Whiter Shade of Pale"
57th on its list of the [500 Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/List_of_Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "List of
Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time").

In 1977, the song was named joint winner (along with
[Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(band\) "Queen \(band\)")'s "[Bohemian
Rhapsody](/wiki/Bohemian_Rhapsody "Bohemian Rhapsody")") of "The Best British
Pop Single 1952–1977" at the [Brit Awards](/wiki/Brit_Awards "Brit
Awards").[9] In 1998 the song was inducted into the [Grammy Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame "Grammy Hall of Fame").[10] More than 1000
recorded cover versions by other artists are known.[11] The song has been
included in many music compilations over the decades and has also been used in
the soundtracks of numerous films, including _[The Big
Chill](/wiki/The_Big_Chill_\(film\) "The Big Chill \(film\)")_ , _[Purple
Haze](/wiki/Purple_Haze_\(film\) "Purple Haze \(film\)")_ , _[Breaking the
Waves](/wiki/Breaking_the_Waves "Breaking the Waves")_ , _[The Boat That
Rocked](/wiki/The_Boat_That_Rocked "The Boat That Rocked")_ , [Martin
Scorsese](/wiki/Martin_Scorsese "Martin Scorsese")'s segment of _[New York
Stories](/wiki/New_York_Stories "New York Stories")_ ,
_[Stonewall](/wiki/Stonewall "Stonewall")_ , and [Ken Burns](/wiki/Ken_Burns
"Ken Burns") and [Lynn Novick](/wiki/Lynn_Novick "Lynn Novick")'s documentary
series _[The Vietnam War](/wiki/The_Vietnam_War_\(TV_series\) "The Vietnam War
\(TV series\)")_. Cover versions of the song have also been featured in many
films, for example, by [King Curtis](/wiki/King_Curtis "King Curtis") in
_[Withnail and I](/wiki/Withnail_and_I "Withnail and I")_ and by [Annie
Lennox](/wiki/Annie_Lennox "Annie Lennox") in _[The
Net](/wiki/The_Net_\(1995_film\) "The Net \(1995 film\)")_.

The original writing credits were for Brooker and Reid only. On 30 July 2009,
Matthew Fisher won co-writing credit for the music in a unanimous ruling from
the [Law Lords](/wiki/Law_Lords "Law Lords").

## Recording and
personnel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Recording and personnel")]

The song was performed and recorded at [Olympic Sound
Studios](/wiki/Olympic_Sound_Studios "Olympic Sound Studios") in
[London](/wiki/London "London"), England, with [Gary
Brooker](/wiki/Gary_Brooker "Gary Brooker") providing the vocals and piano,
[Matthew Fisher](/wiki/Matthew_Fisher "Matthew Fisher") on a [Hammond
M-102](/wiki/Hammond_Organ#M-100_series "Hammond Organ") organ, [David
Knights](/wiki/David_Knights "David Knights") on bass and [Ray
Royer](/wiki/Ray_Royer "Ray Royer") on guitar. Drums were by session drummer
[Bill Eyden](/wiki/Bill_Eyden "Bill Eyden"). A few days later, the song was
re-recorded with the band's then newly recruited drummer [Bobby
Harrison](/wiki/Bobby_Harrison "Bobby Harrison"), but that version was
discarded, and one of the original mono recordings was chosen for release.

Producer for the record was [Denny Cordell](/wiki/Denny_Cordell "Denny
Cordell"), and Keith Grant was the sound engineer.[12] The song was included
on the US release of the _[Procol Harum](/wiki/Procol_Harum_\(album\) "Procol
Harum \(album\)")_ album, in September 1967, but not on the later UK
version.[13]

##
Lyrics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Lyrics")]

Reid got the title and starting point for the song at a party. He overheard
someone at the party saying to a woman, "You've turned a whiter shade of
pale", and the phrase stuck in his mind.[14][15] The original lyrics had four
verses, of which only two are heard on the original recording. The third verse
has been heard in live performances by Procol Harum, and more seldom also the
fourth.[16] The author of _Procol Harum: Beyond the Pale_ , Claes Johansen,
suggests that the song "deals in metaphorical form with a male/female
relationship which after some negotiation ends in a sexual act".[15] This is
supported by [Tim de Lisle](/wiki/Tim_de_Lisle "Tim de Lisle") in _Lives of
the Great Songs_ , who remarks that the lyrics concern a drunken seduction,
which is described through references to sex as a form of travel, usually
nautical, using mythical and literary journeys.[17] Other observers have also
commented that the lyrics concern a sexual relationship.[14]

Contrary to the above interpretations, Reid was quoted in the February 2008
issue of _[Uncut](/wiki/Uncut_\(magazine\) "Uncut \(magazine\)")_ magazine as
saying:

> I was trying to conjure a mood as much as tell a straightforward, girl-
> leaves-boy story. With the ceiling flying away and room humming harder, I
> wanted to paint an image of a scene. I wasn’t trying to be mysterious with
> those images, I was trying to be evocative. I suppose it seems like a
> decadent scene I’m describing. But I was too young to have experienced any
> decadence, then. I might have been smoking when I conceived it, but not when
> I wrote. It was influenced by books, not drugs.

Structurally and thematically, the song is unusual in many respects. While the
recorded version is 4:03 long, it is composed of only two verses, each with
chorus. The piece is also more instrument-driven than most songs of the
period, and with a much looser [rhyme scheme](/wiki/Rhyme_scheme "Rhyme
scheme"). Its unusually allusive and referential lyrics are much more complex
than most lyrics of the time (for example, the chorus focuses on
[Chaucer](/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer "Geoffrey Chaucer")'s "[The Miller's
Tale](/wiki/The_Miller%27s_Tale "The Miller's Tale")"). Thus, this piece can
be considered an early example of [progressive rock](/wiki/Progressive_rock
"Progressive rock").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The phrase _a whiter shade of pale_ has since gained widespread use in the
English language, noticed by several dictionaries.[18][19][20] As such, the
phrase is today often used in contexts independent of any consideration of the
song.[21] It has also been heavily paraphrased, in forms like "an Xer shade of
Y", to the extent that it has been recognised as a [snowclone](/wiki/Snowclone
"Snowclone")[22][23] – a type of [cliché](/wiki/Clich%C3%A9 "Cliché") and
[phrasal template](/wiki/Phrasal_template "Phrasal template").

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Composition")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Expo_Pink_Floyd_-
_Organ.jpg/220px-Expo_Pink_Floyd_-_Organ.jpg)](/wiki/File:Expo_Pink_Floyd_-
_Organ.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Expo_Pink_Floyd_-_Organ.jpg "Enlarge")

The song's distinctive, Bach-inspired organ part was played on a [Hammond
M102](/wiki/Hammond_organ "Hammond organ").

The song is in moderate time in [C major](/wiki/C_major "C major") and is
characterised by the [bassline](/wiki/Bassline "Bassline") moving stepwise
downwards in a repeated pattern throughout. In classical music this is known
as a [ground bass](/wiki/Ground_bass "Ground bass"). The harmonic structure is
identical for the organ melody, the verse and the chorus, except that the
chorus finishes with a [cadence](/wiki/Cadence_\(music\) "Cadence \(music\)").
The main organ melody appears at the beginning and after each verse/chorus.
But it is also heard throughout, playing variations of its theme and
[counterpointing](/wiki/Counterpoint "Counterpoint") the vocal line. As the
chorus commences "And so it was, and later ...", the vocal and organ
accompaniment begin a short [crescendo](/wiki/Crescendo "Crescendo"), with the
organist running his finger rapidly down and up the entire keyboard. The final
instrumental fades out to silence – a common device in pop music of the time.

Dutch author, and Bach aficionado, [Maarten 't Hart](/wiki/Maarten_%27t_Hart
"Maarten 't Hart") calls "A Whiter Shade of Pale" an "original adaptation" of
[Johann Sebastian Bach](/wiki/Johann_Sebastian_Bach "Johann Sebastian Bach")'s
[Ich steh mit einem Fuß im Grabe, BWV
156](/wiki/Ich_steh_mit_einem_Fu%C3%9F_im_Grabe,_BWV_156 "Ich steh mit einem
Fuß im Grabe, BWV 156"). Besides, the [Hammond organ](/wiki/Hammond_organ
"Hammond organ") line of the song came from Bach's "[Sleepers,
Wake!](/wiki/Wachet_auf,_ruft_uns_die_Stimme,_BWV_140 "Wachet auf, ruft uns
die Stimme, BWV 140")" and "[Air on the G String](/wiki/Air_on_the_G_String
"Air on the G String")", both of which use a similar stepwise bass motion. The
similarity is referred to in the 1982 play [_The Real
Thing_](/wiki/The_Real_Thing_\(play\) "The Real Thing \(play\)") by [Tom
Stoppard](/wiki/Tom_Stoppard "Tom Stoppard") and 1991 film [_The
Commitments_](/wiki/The_Commitments_\(film\) "The Commitments \(film\)"). A
yet closer melodic influence that is seldom cited can arguably[_[weasel
words](/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words "Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words")_] be
found in the organ choral prelude "O Mensch bewein dein' Sünde groß" (O Man,
Lament Your Sin So Great), [BWV](/wiki/BWV "BWV") 622, from Bach's
_[Orgelbüchlein](/wiki/Orgelb%C3%BCchlein "Orgelbüchlein")_ (Little Organ
Book). The music also borrows ideas from "[When a Man Loves a
Woman](/wiki/When_a_Man_Loves_a_Woman_\(song\) "When a Man Loves a Woman
\(song\)")" by [Percy Sledge](/wiki/Percy_Sledge "Percy Sledge").[24]

## Release and
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Release and reception")]

The single was released on 12 May 1967 in the United Kingdom by [Deram
Records](/wiki/Deram_Records "Deram Records") and entered _[Record
Retailer](/wiki/Record_Retailer "Record Retailer")_ 's chart (later the [UK
Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart")) on 25 May. In two
weeks it reached number 1, where it stayed for six weeks. Writing in 2005, Jim
Irvin of _[Mojo](/wiki/Mojo_\(magazine\) "Mojo \(magazine\)")_ said that its
arrival at number 1 on 8 June 1967, on the same day that [the
Beatles](/wiki/The_Beatles "The Beatles")' _[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club
Band](/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely
Hearts Club Band")_ topped the national albums chart, marked the start of the
[Summer of Love](/wiki/Summer_of_Love "Summer of Love") in Britain.[25]

According to music journalist and author Harvey Kubernik, in the context of
the Summer of Love, "A Whiter Shade of Pale" was the "one song [that] stood
above all others, its Everest-like status conferred by no less than [John
Lennon](/wiki/John_Lennon "John Lennon") and [Paul
McCartney](/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney"), who were enthralled by the
Chaucerian wordplay and heavenly Baroque accompaniment".[13] Kubernik also
writes that, amid the search for higher consciousness during the [flower
power](/wiki/Flower_power "Flower power") era, the song "galvanised a
congregation of disaffected youth dismissive of traditional religion but
anxious to achieve spiritual salvation".[26]

In the United States, the single reached number 5 on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") and sold over 1 million
copies. It also peaked at number 22 on the soul charts there.[27] In the
Netherlands, the song entered the chart at number 1 in June 1967 and again
reached number 1 in July 1972. A May 1972 re-release on [Fly
Records](/wiki/Fly_Records "Fly Records") stayed in the UK charts for a total
of 12 weeks and peaked at number 13.

"A Whiter Shade of Pale" has continued to receive critical acclaim. Along with
[Queen](/wiki/Queen_\(band\) "Queen \(band\)")'s "[Bohemian
Rhapsody](/wiki/Bohemian_Rhapsody "Bohemian Rhapsody")", "A Whiter Shade of
Pale" was jointly recognised as "The Best British Pop Single 1952–1977" at the
[BRIT Awards](/wiki/BRIT_Awards "BRIT Awards"), part of [Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II")'s [Silver Jubilee](/wiki/Silver_Jubilee
"Silver Jubilee"). In 1998 the song was inducted into the [Grammy Hall of
Fame](/wiki/Grammy_Hall_of_Fame "Grammy Hall of Fame"). In 2004, it appeared
at number 57 on _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_
magazine's list of the "[500 Greatest Songs of All
Time](/wiki/List_of_Rolling_Stone%27s_500_Greatest_Songs_of_All_Time "List of
Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time")". British TV station [Channel
4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") placed the song at number 19 in its chart of
"The 100 Greatest No. 1 Singles".[28]

## Promotional
films[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Promotional films")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/The_conservatory%2C_Witley_Court.jpg/190px-
The_conservatory%2C_Witley_Court.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_conservatory,_Witley_Court.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_conservatory,_Witley_Court.jpg "Enlarge")

One of the clips for the song was filmed at [Witley Court](/wiki/Witley_Court
"Witley Court"), part of which was gutted by fire in 1937.

The first promotional clip for "A Whiter Shade of Pale" was shot in the ruins
of [Witley Court](/wiki/Witley_Court "Witley Court") in Worcestershire,
England.[29] It features four of the five musicians who played on the hit
single: Gary Brooker, Matthew Fisher, David Knights and Ray Royer, in
performance and walking through the ruins. Only the drummer in the video isn't
on the record: early band member Bobby Harrison is seen miming to session man
Bill Eyden's drumming. The film was directed by [Peter
Clifton](/wiki/Peter_Clifton "Peter Clifton"), whose insertion of [Vietnam
War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") newsreel footage caused it to be banned
from airplay on the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC")'s _[Top of the
Pops](/wiki/Top_of_the_Pops "Top of the Pops")_ TV show.[30]

Procol Harum subsequently made a second promotional clip, using
"[Scopitone](/wiki/Scopitone "Scopitone")" technology. By this time, [Robin
Trower](/wiki/Robin_Trower "Robin Trower") and [B.J. Wilson](/wiki/B.J._Wilson
"B.J. Wilson") had replaced Royer and Harrison in the band, so only three of
the five musicians on the recording are represented. No performance footage
appears in this film – only scenes of the five musicians cavorting around
London and running across fields. The same lineup, with Fisher wearing a
monk's [cowl](/wiki/Cowl "Cowl"), mimed to the song on _Top of the Pops_ ,
although Brooker sang live. Black-and-white footage of the performance has
been shown online. The song represents 1967 in the 2004 release _[Top of the
Pops 40th Anniversary 1964–2004
DVD](/wiki/Top_of_the_Pops_40th_Anniversary_1964%E2%80%932004_DVD "Top of the
Pops 40th Anniversary 1964–2004 DVD")_.

There was also a film shot as part of [Joel Gallen](/wiki/Joel_Gallen "Joel
Gallen")'s Deja-View music video series.[31] Originally airing on various
networks in late 1985 through 1986, this video starred [Harry Dean
Stanton](/wiki/Harry_Dean_Stanton "Harry Dean Stanton") and [Bernie
Taupin](/wiki/Bernie_Taupin "Bernie Taupin"), but featured no member of the
band. It has also aired on [VH1 Classic](/wiki/VH1_Classic "VH1 Classic"), and
has recently surfaced online.[32][33]

## Authorship
lawsuit[[edit](/w/index.php?title=A_Whiter_Shade_of_Pale&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Authorship lawsuit")]

In 2005, former Procol Harum organist [Matthew Fisher](/wiki/Matthew_Fisher
"Matthew Fisher") filed suit in the [High Court](/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice
"High Court of Justice") against Gary Brooker and his publisher, claiming that
he co-wrote the music for the song.[34] Fisher won the case on 20 December
2006 but was awarded 40% of the composers' share of the music copyright,
rather than the 50% he was seeking and was not granted royalties for the
period before 2005.[35]

Brooker and publisher Onward Music were granted leave to appeal, and a hearing
on the matter was held before a panel of three judges during the week of 1
October 2007. The decision, on 4 April 2008, by [Lord Justice
Mummery](/wiki/Lord_Justice_Mummery "Lord Justice Mummery"), in the [Court of
Appeal](/wiki/Court_of_Appeal_of_England_and_Wales "Court of Appeal of England
and Wales") upheld Fisher's co-authorship[36] but ruled that he should receive
no royalties as he had taken too long (38 years) to bring his claim to
litigation. Full royalty rights were returned to Brooker.[37]

On 5 November 2008, Fisher was granted permission to appeal this decision to
the [House of Lords](/wiki/Judicial_functions_of_the_House_of_Lords "Judicial
functions of the House of Lords").[38] Lawyers say it is the first time the
Law Lords have been asked to rule on a copyright dispute involving a song.[39]
The appeal was heard in the House of Lords on 22–23 April 2009.[40]

On 30 July 2009 the Law Lords unanimously ruled in Fisher's favour. They noted
that the delay in bringing the case had not caused any harm to the other
party; on the contrary he had benefited financially from it. They also pointed
out that there were no time limits to copyright claims under English law. The
right to future royalties was therefore returned to Fisher.[41][42] The
musicological basis of the judgment, and its effect on the rights of musicians
who contribute composition to future works, has drawn some attention in the
music world.[43]

**" A Whiter Shade of Pale"** was covered by [Annie Lennox](/wiki/Annie_Lennox
"Annie Lennox") for her 1995 album
_[Medusa](/wiki/Medusa_\(Annie_Lennox_album\) "Medusa \(Annie Lennox
album\)")_. It was released as the second single in May 1995 and became a top-
forty hit in Europe and Canada.
